results.title: The Fiddlers of James Bay
results.creator_credit: Bob Rodgers, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Scots from the Orkney Islands came to trade in Northern Quebec during the 17th century. They brought fiddles with them and introduced a new form of music to the Cree of James Bay. The music survived long after the Scots returned home. In this film two Cree fiddlers travel to the Orkney Islands, the birthplace of the music they learned from their fathers and grandfathers. The film captures the warmth and good will of this reunion.

results.title: The Fibre web
results.creator_credit: Henry Cooper, Alan Harper and Campbell Harper Films
results.brief_description: Shows the manufacture of high-quality paper in Scotland, and its uses throughout the world. Today, the uses of paper extend beyond visible applications for books, or maps, labels, or cheques, to become the insulators for telephone cables, giant transformers or computers. Narrated by Kenneth Horne.

results.title: The Ferrara poems
results.creator_credit: Jenny Robertson, S A Department for the Arts and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Two Australian travellers Karl (Michael Snelling) and Giselle (Kerin Murray) meet up with friends at a cafe in Italy for coffee and discuss their cultural experiences and observations of the country. A trip is planned and the group sets off together on another sight-seeing adventure. A postmodernist film essay exploring the structure of storytelling through the deliberate raw use of cinematic and film making devices (making those devices transparent). A film about foreigners, film making and foreign processes. Cast also includes: Ken Bolton, Mark Thomson and Tish Banks. Narrator: Richard Grayson.

results.title: The Ferals [Puppets]
results.credit_line:
Designed by Garth Frost

Puppet maker Tina Matthews

Australia, 1993

Courtesy of Emma de Vries

Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020
results.brief_description: “They discovered fame and fortune and they’re never going back.” Or so proclaimed the catchy hook of The Ferals TV theme song. This kids’ program debuted on ABC TV in 1994 and then, after two successful seasons, it has endured in Australian pop culture. Capitalising on the grunge aesthetic of the time, it followed an unruly bunch of feral animals living in a share house with flatmates played by human actors. The ditzy rabbit Mixy and sassy cat Modigliana were key members of the show, adding to the tradition of children’s programming featuring puppets in starring roles, including Lift Off (1992-95) and Mr Squiggle (1959-99).

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

results.title: The Ferals
results.creator_credit: David Evans, Wendy Gray and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: The Ferals are the original urban wild bunch. Rattus is tough, streetwise and constantly arguing with Modigliana, the cat with a definite sense of style, if not taste. With Mixy the rabbit and Derryn, the not too bright dog, they hang out in the shed at the bottom of Joe’s garden. “An explosion of talent”: The Feral’s performance at a talent quest is helped enormously by Leonard’s new invention - the Digital Volume Enhancer, until Modi pulls the wrong switch. “Double trouble”: As if one Rattus wasn’t trouble enough! Rattus and Joe’s ‘get-rich’quick’ scheme goes awfully wrong so it’s just as well that the Digital Duplicator has a reverse mode.

results.title: The Fenlands
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Regional Geography”.
The Fenlands situated in Eastern England are one of the flattest regions of Britain. The Fenland landscape is almost wholly manmade, being the result of draining the land, to make it available for agriculture. The danger of flooding is ever present, and in 1947 a disastrous flood occurred. In an attempt to overcome the problem, an extensive sluice system has been devised.

results.title: The Feminine mistake
results.creator_credit: Arnold Shapiro, Dave Bell Associates and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: A realistic look at what happens to women who smoke, showing young smokers, a pregnant woman, cancer victims, habitual smokers with wrinkled faces, and tests showing how one cigarette affects vital body organs. Shows a successful program in progress at one high school which is aimed at discouraging smoking among teenagers. Hosted by Bonnie Franklin

results.title: The Fell locomotive
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Roy Harris and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: A description of a new locomotive being produced in England. This is the first completely diesel engine to be evolved and an entirely new method of transmitting power to the wheels is incorporated in it. The film illustrates the advantages it has over steam, electric and diesel electric locomotives.

results.title: The Feeling of rejection: its development and growth
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The case history of Margaret, a 23-year-old girl who has physical disorders with no physical causes. A psychiatrist shows her the root of her troubles—childhood overprotection and discouragement of her efforts to express herself, resulting in a crippling fear of failure and a complete inability to assert herself. When Margaret understands her problem, she develops new and healthier habits of behavior. (Awards: Chicago; Rome; Manila.) Produced for the Dept. of National Health and Welfare.
